title: 108_s2584
content: The Act titled "Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004" provides a credit for farmer investment in value-added agricultural property under section 45G of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004 offers a 50% credit on the basis of qualified value-added agricultural property placed in service during the taxable year for eligible persons or farmer-owned entities. The credit is allocated among eligible persons in a farmer-owned entity on a pro rata basis. The credit is allocated on a pro rata basis among eligible persons holding qualified interests in the entity. The maximum credit for property placed in service by an eligible person is $30,000, reduced by creditable investments allowed for the taxable year. For property placed in service by a farmer-owned entity, the credit is determined based on specific criteria. The credit for property placed in service by a farmer-owned entity is based on the eligible person's creditable investments in the entity. Creditable investments refer to the amount invested in the entity for the property placed in service. The credit for property placed in service by a farmer-owned entity is based on the eligible person's creditable investments in the entity, which are the qualified investments made by the person in the entity for the property placed in service. The credit for property placed in service by a farmer-owned entity is reduced by the sum of the qualified investments made by the person in the entity for property previously placed in service and in all other farmer-owned entities. The aggregate qualified investments made by an eligible person in farmer-owned entities for property previously placed in service shall not exceed $30,000. The maximum qualified investments by an eligible person for any taxable year is $30,000. Qualified value-added agricultural property refers to property used to add value to goods derived from renewable organic matter. The curr_chunk discusses renewable organic matter sources eligible for depreciation or amortization with a useful life of 3 years or more. The curr_chunk discusses renewable organic matter sources eligible for depreciation or amortization with a useful life of 3 years or more, owned and operated by an eligible person or a farmer-owned entity. Eligible person refers to someone materially participating in an eligible farming business. A person who materially participates in an eligible farming business is considered an eligible person for depreciation or amortization purposes. Material participation is determined similarly to section 2032A(e)(6), and for entities like corporations or partnerships, it is assessed at the shareholder or partner level. For depreciation or amortization purposes, a person materially participating in an eligible farming business is considered an eligible person. Material participation is determined at the shareholder or partner level for entities like corporations or partnerships. An eligible farming business is defined as a farming business that is not a passive activity. A farmer-owned entity is defined as a farming business that is not a passive activity, where eligible persons own a majority of voting power and stock. Eligible persons must own a majority of voting power and stock in a farmer-owned entity, partnership, or cooperative. Eligible persons must own a majority of voting power and stock in a farmer-owned entity, partnership, or cooperative. Constructive ownership rules apply, with family members defined in subparagraph (C). In applying section 263A(e)(2)(B), family members of an individual include spouse, children, grandchildren, great grandchildren, and their spouses residing in the same household or jointly operating farming businesses. The term 'qualified investments' refers to cash payments for purchasing qualified investments, including family members such as spouses, children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren residing in the same household or jointly operating farming businesses. Adopted children are also considered as family members for this purpose. The term 'qualified investments' includes cash payments for purchasing qualified equity interests in farmer-owned entities, such as stock in a domestic corporation acquired by the taxpayer between December 31, 2004, and January 1, 2011. The taxpayer can qualify for certain investments, such as stock in a domestic corporation, acquired between December 31, 2004, and January 1, 2011, solely in exchange for cash. The taxpayer may qualify for certain investments, such as stock in a domestic corporation or a patronage interest in a cooperative, acquired between December 31, 2004, and January 1, 2011. Special rules apply for married individuals. Special rules apply for married individuals filing separate returns, with a reduced threshold of $15,000 instead of $30,000 for certain investments made between December 31, 2004, and January 1, 2011. Special rules apply for married individuals filing separate returns, with a reduced threshold of $15,000 instead of $30,000 for certain investments made between December 31, 2004, and January 1, 2011. Regulations prescribe allocation of credit for estates and trusts, and basis adjustment for qualified value-added agricultural property. The basis of qualified value-added agricultural property is adjusted by reducing it by the amount of the credit allowed and increasing it by any recapture under subsection (e) within a 5-year period. Within a 5-year period, rules similar to section 50(a) apply if qualified value-added agricultural property ceases to be eligible, is disposed of, or undergoes changes. Within a 5-year period, rules similar to section 50(a) apply if qualified value-added agricultural property ceases to be eligible, is disposed of, or undergoes changes. The period can be suspended in the event of the eligible person's death. The period in paragraph (1) regarding qualified value-added agricultural property can be suspended for 2 years after the eligible person's death. If an heir is also an eligible person, special rules apply to the transfer of property. The Secretary will prescribe regulations to carry out the section's purposes. The section does not apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2010. Section 38(b) of the Code is amended to allow the credit as part of the general business credit. The section does not apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2010. Section 38(b) of the Code is amended to allow the credit as part of the general business credit. The amendment allows for a new paragraph regarding the value-added agricultural property investment credit under section 45G(a). Additionally, the amendment includes the value-added agricultural property credit in the general business credit under section 38 of the Code. The amendment adds a new paragraph defining the value-added agricultural property credit under section 45G. It also includes this credit in the general business credit under section 38 of the Code. The term 'value-added agricultural property credit' is defined under section 45G. A conforming amendment includes this credit in the general business credit under section 38 of the Code. Additionally, there is a limitation on carryback of the value-added agricultural property investment credit before the effective date. No portion of the unused business credit attributable to the value-added agricultural property investment credit under section 45G can be carried back to any taxable year before the enactment of section 45G. Additionally, subsection (c) of section 196 of the Code is amended to adjust certain unused business credits. The enactment of section 45G prohibits carrying back unused business credits related to the value-added agricultural property investment credit. Amendments to subsection (c) of section 196 of the Code adjust these credits. Basis adjustment in section 1016 is also modified. Amendments to section 1016 of the Code include basis adjustment for payments with a credit under section 38. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The amendments made by this section apply to qualified investments in value-added agricultural property made after December 31, 2004.
